title: 109_hr1217
content: The Act titled "Latin America Military Training Review Act of 2005" suspends the authority for the Western Hemisphere Institute for Security Cooperation. The Act suspends the operation of the Western Hemisphere Institute for Security Cooperation and the authority to operate an education and training facility for Latin American military personnel until a report is submitted. No new training or education facility can be established until the report is submitted. Establishment of a joint congressional task force to assess education and training for Latin American military personnel. Task force composed of eight Members of Congress. Report due within six months, including assessment of courses and curriculum. The curr_chunk discusses evaluating the impact of education and training on Latin American military personnel regarding human rights, democratic principles, and the rule of law. The term "Member" includes Delegates and Resident Commissioners in Congress. The curr_chunk discusses establishing a commission to investigate human rights abuses at the United States Army School of the Americas. Establishment of a commission to investigate activities at the United States Army School of the Americas and its successor institution, the Western Hemisphere Institute for Security Cooperation. The commission will consist of eight members appointed by key leaders in Congress, with qualifications in foreign military training and human rights. Members must not be federal government officers or employees. The commission members must be appointed within 60 days of the Act's enactment, vacancies do not affect its powers, the Chairperson and Vice Chairperson are elected by members, members serve without pay, and receive travel expenses. The commission has the power to conduct hearings and sessions. The commission has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence. It can also obtain necessary information from Federal agencies. Within two years of all members being appointed, the commission must investigate the activities of the United States Army School of the Americas and its successor institution. The commission has the authority to investigate the United States Army School of the Americas and its successor institution, the Western Hemisphere Institute for Security Cooperation. The investigation aims to identify individuals responsible for advocating tactics violating international or US laws, determine how these manuals were used in training, assess the training's impact, and identify those responsible for teaching such tactics. A report with investigation results and recommendations must be submitted to Congress and the Secretary of Defense within 30 days of completing the investigation. The commission will investigate violations of human rights linked to training at the United States Army School of the Americas or its successor institution. It will submit a report with recommendations to Congress and the Secretary of Defense within 30 days of completing the investigation. The commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report.
